titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The House of Representatives this day concurred in all the amendments introduced by the Senate into the Bank Bill— So that it has pass’d both branches of the Legislature— The Senate pass’d the bill respecting Usury—and discuss’d further the report on Jonathan Simpson’s petition— At 12 o’clock they came to a choice of a Senator of the United States, instead of Mr: Foster— 27 Votes—17 for Mr: Pickering— I dined at Mr: Scott’s with the Governor and a company of about twenty Gentlemen— I was called out in the afternoon by one of Mr: Sullivan’s sons, to attend in Senate, on the debate of a bill to incorporate the first parish in Charlestown— I went accordingly— As did Mr: Coffin— We sat untill near 8 o’clock, and pass’d the bill. George Measures 2. feet 6 inches 9/10

2. The House of Representatives this day confirm’d the choice of Mr: Pickering, as Senator of the United States— After two trials— At the second of which Mr Pickering had 59 votes of 116— An exact majority. The other business this day transacted was not very important— In the evening, the club was at my house— Mr: Pickman came— Mr: Hellen arrived this evening from his tour to Portland— Caroline and W. Shaw were at a Ball, at Mrs: B. Welles’s, and came home between 1 and 2. in the morning.

3. The Boston Bank Bill on the question of enactment had a sharp contest again this day in both houses— A vote against it pass’d in the House of Representatives; but was afterwards reconsidered— In the Senate, the yeas and nays were 14 for the bill, and 12 against it— In the evening, I went with Caroline to the Assembly— Mr: Hellen intended to have gone, but found himself so unwell that he concluded not to go. Danced the greater part of the Evening— It was past one in the morning, when we came home, and found Mrs: Adams waiting for us.

4. Several bills for New-Banks pass’d the Senate— My reasons for dissenting from the address to remove the two eastern judges were taken up, and leave was given by a small majority to enter them upon the Journals. The President took a part rather too decided, against me, on this question; as indeed he has done upon every considerable question but one, which I have brought forward in both sessions of this Legislature— I can trace the source of his opposition— The cause is irremoveable— This day commences the Congressional year; and last Evening, I took the sense of the Senate, on the question whether those of us who are elected to serve in the Congress now to ensue, may retain or vacate their seats here— They determined that it had been settled ten years ago, in the cases of Mr: Cobb and Mr: Coffin that the seats here are not vacated; as no man is a member of Congress untill duly qualified and admitted— We went this Evening to the play; and saw The Mountaineers and Paul and Virginia— Mrs: Adams came home and went to bed very ill.

5. Reported a Bill for procuring semi-annual statements from all the Banks, which was twice read, and pass’d to be engross’d— The Senate took up the Judiciary Bill, which came from the house, and unanimously rejected every part of it, but the provision for the Salary to the Judges— This, they adopted, but it will undoubtedly be rejected by the house, and there the whole bill will drop. In the afternoon I went out to Quincy, after dining, with Mr: Hellen and W. Shaw, at Mr: Smith’s.

6. Heard Mr: Flint, of Cohasset— I had scarcely any time to read or write as usual this day— Mr: Hellen, and our Ladies came out from Boston to dinner— We all return’d home together in the Evening. Last Thursday—the 3d: instt:— Just after dinner, a person came into our house, went up into Caroline’s chamber, stole and carried away, a gold watch— Several yards of lace, and sundry other articles— Last evening, the same person was detected performing a similar atchievement in Mr: T. Davis’s house— T’is a young woman, who has within the last three weeks laid at least eight or ten houses in this town under contribution in this manner, and untill now, without detection.

7. Mr: Hartshorn the Deputy Sheriff brought home some of the articles stolen last week; the Ladies went this forenoon to the Sheriff’s, Mr: Allen’s, and took the remainder— The Session of the General Court is closing. We sat this evening untill after 7— Simpson’s petition was referred over to the next General Court— His demand is just, but I think he never will obtain any thing of it.

8. This morning on entering the Senate, I found they had sent to the Secretary’s Office, for the bill to restrain excessive usury, which had pass’d both houses to be enacted— It was sent for, upon a suggestion that the Governor, had doubts about signing it— The Secretary soon brought it in; upon which there was a motion to reconsider the vote of enacting, and refer the bill over— I objected to this mode of proceeding as irregular; and moved that the bill be sent back to the Secretary;—and if the Governor had objections to the bill, he would take the Constitutional mode of expressing them— The bill was sent back— The Governor return’d the bill with objections— The question on the bill was then taken by yeas and nays— General Skinner alone voted for it. Of course the bill is lost— This afternoon,—The Secretary came and signified the Governor’s assent to 104 acts, pass’d this Session, and adjourn’d the Legislature according to the usual mode, to the day next preceding the last Wednesday in May— Pass’d the Evening at home.

9. Mrs: Adams was seiz’d with extreme violence in the night—about midnight— We were all up with her about three hours— Dr: Welsh here, for an hour— She continued very ill all this day— But at night appeared something better— I attended at the Supreme Court this forenoon— The Attorney General fell into a fit, in Court, and was carried home. I pass’d the afternoon at the Bankrupt Office— To make a dividend in the case of Mr: Callender— Usurious debts claimed, and their decision transferr’d to a Jury— Evening at home.

10. Mrs. Adams continued confined to her chamber this day, though somewhat better— Mr: Hellen left us, and took the Stage for Providence at 9 this morning— Attended a trial at the Supreme Court, for burglary.— At the Bankrupt Office, on Callender’s case— Dined at Mr: Quincy’s— Judge Davis and Judge Dawes there— Evening at home with Mrs: Adams— Caroline went to the Ball, with Miss Oliver.

11. Attended at the Supreme Court this forenoon— Executed with Mr: James Lloyd junr: and Mr: John Prince, indentures, by which we take to hold in trust, certain lands and real estate, for Mrs: Apthorp, wife of George Apthorp— Dined at Mr: Parsons’s with the Judges of the Supreme Court— Evening with the Society— Mr: Quincy made several chemical experiments.

12. Heard part of an argument of Mr: Parsons to the Supreme Court— Dined at Concert Hall with the fire-club. My mother came to town with Louisa Smith, and I went out to Quincy with them after dinner. The roads very bad, as the frost is breaking up.
13. Heard Mr: Whitney— My Uncle Adams dined with us— I continued my translation from Luzac, and also wrote a short letter to my brother— Spent of course all my leisure time at the Office.

14. Came in to Boston this morning— Attended the town meeting for the choice of town-officers— Several candidates for treasurer— After one trial for a choice the meeting adjourned to 4. p.m.—to make the second— This likewise failed— At the third Benjn: Sumner was chosen— Remainder of the afternoon at my Office— Evening at home— Reading the Merry Wives of Windsor, and Measure for Measure to the ladies.

15. Attended all the morning at the Supreme Court, on the trial of J. May, for a nuisance in continuing a wharf below low water mark— It was not finished— Dined at Mr: S. Cobb’s, with a company of 15 gentlemen— At my Office— Walk in the Mall— Evening at home— Mr: Gardner called— Reading Measure for Measure.

16. The trial of Mr: May was this day continued at the Supreme Court; but not finished— Mr: Shaw went to the ordination of Mr: Bates at Dedham— Dr: Tufts called at my Office— I engaged to take ten shares in the Quincy and Weymouth turnpike— Afternoon at my Office— Walk’d in the Mall. Evening with the Club at Judge Davis’s.

17. The cause of Mr: May was at length committed to the Jury— I was all the forenoon in Court— Afternoon at my Office— Spent the evening at Mr: Smith’s— Mrs: Parsons and two of her daughters—Mr: C. Miller and his lady were there— We had a thunder shower this morning; and rain all day.

18. The Supreme Court this morning pass’d sentence upon their convicts— After which they heard an argument on a point of Law— I was there part of the forenoon. Mrs: Adams and Caroline, went with Mr: Shaw to Roxbury to look at an house— Mr: Sumner and Mr: Gardner called at my Office— Evening with the Society— Mr: Quincy continued his experiments, and finished his turn of performance.

19. The Directors of Neponset Bridge met at my Office at 12 o’clock— Agreed upon an assessment of 20 dollars a share, to be paid on the first of May— We determined to go on Monday to fix upon the spot where the Bridge shall be built, and to lay out the road— Dined at Mr: George Blake, with the judges of the Supreme Court. Went out to Quincy, in the evening.

20. Heard Mr: M’Kean of Milton— His afternoon performance was excellent— Rest of the day and evening I spent in writing— Continued translating the Oration de Socrate Give. Drawing towards a close of it.

21. Went down to Mr: Quincy’s house this morning; met there Mr: Beale and Mr: Black— Mr: Smith and Mr: Quincy soon after came out from Boston with Mr: Taylor the surveyor— We went to the river, and fixed
fixed the spot where the bridge is to land— Laid out part of the road, but did not complete our business— Mr: Smith, Mr: Quincy, Mr: Taylor and myself dined at Mr: Black’s— In the evening I return’d with the Gentlemen to Boston— Finished reading Measure for Measure to the Ladies.

22. At the Bankrupt Office—to make a dividend for Roylance Child— But the Assignee had nothing. I called at the Treasury Office— Attended the Supreme Court where the Chief-Justice has at length taken his seat— Afternoon at my Office— Evening at home— Read the Comedy of Errors.— Mrs: A. quite ill, after supper—

23. A violent Snow-storm which continued the greatest part of the day, and all this Evening.— I attended in the forenoon at the Supreme Court— Afternoon at my Office— In the evening went with Caroline to a Ball, at Mr: Gardner Greene’s— Danc’d; and play’d Cards— Home, between 12 and 1. Mrs: Adams did not go; being very unwell; and confin’d all day to her chamber.

24. Attended the Supreme Court all the morning, expecting a cause to come on, which however did not. Dined at Judge Davis’s, with several of the Judges, and other Gentlemen— Evening at home— Caroline went to the Ball, with Miss Oliver— Mrs: Adams remains still confin’d.

25. The Supreme Court this day closed their Session, having made but very small progress in the business before them— I Dined in company with fourteen or fifteen Gentlemen at Dr: Warren’s— Walk in the Mall afterwards with Mr: Quincy— Evening with the Society— Mr: Emerson made some experiments upon Alkali’s.

26. Pass’d the forenoon at my Office— Sundry bills—proceeding as I imagine from the operation of the Banks. In the afternoon I went out to Quincy— Mrs: Adams was not able to go— Mr: Shaw went out with Mr: Channing; who stop’d at Milton— We found Mrs: Cranch and Miss Gorham at my father’s house.

27. Heard Mr: Ware of Hingham; who dined with us— I finished the translation of the Oration, de Socrate Cive— And wrote part of a letter— Spent the evening at Mr: Cranch’s—where was Mr: Bracket, and afterwards Mr: Barrett and Mr: Hall— Weather unusually cold, and hard freezing.

28. Return’d to Boston early this morning— Mrs: Cranch came with me— Mr: Shaw came in with Mr Channing— Spent the day at my Office, examining a point of law— Mr: Gardner & Mr Quincy call’d on me— I gave Mr: H. G. Otis a letter for him, which I found yesterday morning in my coat pocket without knowing how it came there— It was from Mr: D. Davis and contained a proxy to vote for him in the Boston Bank— I Spent the evening at home; and read to the Ladies two Acts of the Merchant of Venice.
29. The whole day at my Office very busily engaged, without being able to satisfy myself upon the point of my investigation— Evening at home, and read the remainder of the Merchant of Venice.

30. Went this morning to Dedham, to attend on the Supreme Court, sitting there for the County of Norfolk. Dined with Mr: Townsend— Found Mrs: Cranch at his house— I intended to have return’d at Night— But the Court sat too late— Could get no bed at either of the taverns— Went home with Mr: Cutler the Sheriff of the County; who lives at Roxbury, about half-way from Dedham to Boston— Supp’d and lodged at his house. Saw his lady for the first time— She is from South-Carolina.— And an agreeable woman.

31. We return’d to Dedham early this morning— Tried this forenoon the cause of Baxter Admr: against Curtis— Dined with the Judges at Mrs: Ames’s— Referr’d after dinner, Curtis’s second cause. But I was this day retained by T. Williams to argue another case to-morrow morning; the question is on the validity of the will—the objection insanity and duress on the testator— The Court sat again this evening so late that I could not go home— Took tea and pass’d the evening with the Judges at Mr Ames’s— After which I went by invitation of Mr Townsend to his house—to pass the Night.
Day— As last Month—excepting that my attendance is at my Office, instead of the Senate-Chamber.
